Award.AwardTitle: International Workshop on Energy and Environment in the Development of Sustainable Asphalt Pavements

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this workshop is to facilitate the development of the scientific and technical expertise in asphalt pavement engineering necessary to sustain the new energy economy of the 21st century. Energy and environment play a significant role in the quality of life, world?s economic growth, and stability. The main goal of this workshop is that newly built or rehabilitated roads have to be sustainable, cost-effective and energy saving during construction and service. This workshop will initiate a new education effort designed to train the next generation of technical workers and researchers in the asphalt area. The merit lies in the selection of the attendees - Group one will be selected based on the fact that they have experience in energy, environment, ecology, and sustainability research but not necessarily in asphalt pavement. Group two will be from the asphalt area. Such interaction will lead to the discovery of energy efficient, environment friendly sustainable pavements in near future.

This study may lead to world construction materials recovery and savings through the development of sustainable pavements which is of particular concern in rapidly developing countries such as China. The ideas and opinions of the researchers from two countries namely USA and China will be disseminated through the workshop Website, which will benefit a broader scientific society and engineers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Energy and the environment play a significant role in the quality of life, world?s economic growth, and stability. Many nations such as the U.S. and China depend on foreign oil to meet their energy needs. In addition, the global environment has recently been degraded to such a level that it poses a threat to the world?s stability. At this critical time of dropping energy reserves and threatened global environment, reducing the use of energy and materials to build pavements in an environmentally benign way is vital to ensure the sustainability of our roadway infrastructure, which is one of the biggest infrastructures in the US and China. To that end, the workshop that held on June 6-9, 2010, in Xian, China, covers sustainability and life cycle aspects of pavements. The outcome of the workshop is interactions between two small groups of researchers. ?Group one is comprised of researchers with experience in energy, environment, ecology, and sustainability, but not necessarily in asphalt pavement. Group two is comprised of researchers in the asphalt area. The workshop attendees consisted of 12 people from the US and 12 people from China in each of the areas listed above (sustainability and asphalt). ?As a participant, each participated the brain-storming discussion sessions, wrote a short paper, and made a PowerPoint presentation. The workshop has identified the following new potentials and the required research:


Outcome Related to Energy

Energy saving in asphalt pavement construction and rehabilitation can be achieved through the use of recycled asphalt materials (RAP), warm mix asphalt, self-healing properties of asphalt, rubber (tire), polymer, nano-clays, anti-stripping chemicals, and reduced construction emission. In addition, there exists the potential to extract heat from pavement during the summer as useable thermal energy; and the potential for generating electricity by utilizing traffic loading.

?

Outcome Related to Environment

Porous pavement, warm mix asphalt, and recycling technologies are healthy technologies that can directly lower energy costs, green house gas emissions, industrial ecology, and environmental pollutions. These emerging technologies need further research, assessment, and favoring policy for deployment. The workshop has identified these technologies, assessment methods, and brainstorm policies for deployment.

?

Outcome Related to Sustainability

A sustainable asphalt pavement can be defined as an HMA pavement designed and built to last more than 50 years without requiring major structural rehabilitation or reconstruction. Increased healing and decreased aging can be incorporated in characterizing and fabricating smart paving materials for building sustainable pavements. Innovative use of smart materials and new adaptive pavement structure can realistically lead to sustainable pavements. The workshop has identified research and education opportunities in renewable materials, innovative mix, structure design methods, and efficient construction process for sustainable and environmentally friendly pavements.
